title: 9 best cycling glasses that offer UV, water and wind protection
text:
Many people think that cycling glasses are purely for the trendier kit obsessed cyclist, or just for use on those blue sky sunny days. But they’re an essential piece of safety kit year round in all weathers, almost akin to the helmet.

The lens is of course the most important element – this is what’s going to stop debris or a fly hitting your eye, and also protect from wind, water and UV rays.

If you’re looking for sunglasses to ride in sunny conditions specifically, look for a category-3 rated lens – these will have a heavily reflective or tinted lens and offer a high level of UV protection. However, for more changeable and cloudy conditions, a category 2 or even 1 lens will work, as they provide some UV protection and you’ll be more focused on shielding your face from wind and debris rather than sun.

A fantastic option for unpredictable UK weather is the photochromic lens, as it works equally well in overcast rainy conditions as it does in full sunshine. The lenses respond to changing light levels by increasing or decreasing their darkness.

A number of sunglasses also have interchangeable lenses. These will not only adapt to different scenarios (low light, cloudy, full sun), but if they get scratched, you can easily – and cheaply – replace with a new lens.

We tested a range of cycling glasses with varying lens types to find you the best shades on the market.

You can trust our independent reviews. We may earn commission from some of the retailers, but we never allow this to influence selections, which are formed from real-world testing and expert advice. This revenue helps to fund journalism across The Independent.

Smith rukus: £155, Smith Optics

These glasses are on the premium end of the price-point spectrum, but as soon as you lay your hands on these, they feel the real deal. Slipping onto your face, they grip it perfectly, offering just the right amount of flexibility while feeling nicely secure in all positions (they’ll fit larger faces too). They look fantastic – the frame detailing around the lens makes them noticeable in a good way, and the rubber nosepiece and arm-ends mean they’re really comfy. In the box, you’ll be armed with two interchangeable lenses – one for full sun and the other ideal for overcast; perfect for typical UK riding conditions.

Buy now

Bolle shifter sunglasses: £84.99, RX Sport

These Italian-made sunglasses are a simple and stylish in design, yet strong and functional too. With no central piece bridging from the nose piece to the upper section, there’s nothing to hamper your vision. The lenses have an anti-fog treatment, vents (both top and bottom), and they’re category-3 rated so intended for full sunlight. Photochromic lenses are also available.

Buy now

Ride100percent s3 soft tact flume mirror lens: £159.84, Ride100percent

This US brand is firmly establishing itself among pro riders and for good reason. They have a super wide wrap around lens, so your peripheral field of vision is fantastic, as well as offering protection from the elements.

The rubber nose grip and tipped arms feel very secure, even if you have a slimmer face. These lenses are category 2 (medium UV protection) which is a good level for UK weather conditions, plus they’re coated to keep water off. The lenses are interchangeable too so you can switch to your personal preference.

Buy now

dhb fractal revo lense: From £50, Wiggle

A great snug fitting and lightweight pair, these perfectly encapsulate contemporary road cycling style without going too over the top. Made from a premium-feeling plastic, these are narrower fitting sunglasses. They fit really firmly and the generous frame and lens size gives great visibility. If you are looking for an affordable yet totally capable product to use in sunny conditions (they’re category-3 rated for high UV protection) these are your best bet.

Buy now

Sungod pacebreaker: £85, Sungod

Sungod is the most customisable brand we have come across, offering sunglasses in a range of colourways. They are not totally inline with the “maxi” design trend that’s currently hot on the road biking scene, but are realistically designed for any kind of outdoor action sports – they’re just as well suited to running a marathon as they are for a day in the saddle. They fit really well, have good quality lenses and are a great option at this price point.

Buy now

KOO open cube: £174.99, KOO

KOO is the helmet maker Kask’s sunglasses arm, and these minimal half frame options are fitted with a high quality interchangeable Carl Zeiss lens (they come with two; one clear and one reflective). They’re available in either small or medium frame sizes, so there’ll be no making do with the fit of these –whether you’ve a wider or narrower face they will fit securely and neatly. With an innovative folding arm system, they store particularly neatly.

Buy now

Rudy Project defender: £116.99, Rxsport

These thoroughbred racing options offer a large full frame with wide vision in a super lightweight package. The lens is interchangeable, but these come with a category 2 (mid UV levels) smoke lens – if you’re after photochromic there’s a £50 premium. They’re solidly built, are adjustable on the temples and nosepiece, and for all this functionality, the price point is justified.

Buy now

Decathlon van rysel roadr 900: £34.99, Decathlon

Van Rysel is outdoor retailer Decathlon’s top line of gear, and at this price point you really can’t go wrong. Coming with two interchangeable lenses – category-3 rated for full sun and clear for overcast or night riding – you can easily switch them in a matter of seconds. They feel solidly built, certainly considering the price, and have a good field of vision sitting securely on your face.

Buy now

Oakley jawbreaker: £175, Oakley

The jawbreaker are an eye-catching pair with their distinctive design. With their supersized frame and lens, you have full coverage and visibility, and these particular models have the "prizm" lens which performs well in a large range of light conditions. These also feature a water-deflecting treatment so rain will run off. The rubber at the nosepiece and temples keeps them securely in place.

Buy now

The verdict: Cycling sunglasses

Our standout pair in this roundup are the Smith rukus sunglasses – although a more expensive option, they are lightweight, versatile and a real quality product. If you’re on a budget and prefer a more conventional look, then the Decathlon pair, complete with two interchangeable lenses are hard to beat.

description: Protect your peepers on the road with the best cycling glasses from Smith, dhb, Decathlon and more that are protective and sturdy
